block.p: Lawyers for Stewart Request New Trial Again Martha Stewart's lawyers requested a new trial for her, arguing that lies told by a government witness prevented her from receiving fair treatment. The lawyers also asked for a hearing to determine whether any prosecutors knew that the witness was lying.

It is Ms. Stewart's second attempt at overturning the verdict against her. An earlier request, in which Ms. Stewart's lawyers said a juror had lied on a screening questionnaire, was rejected last month. [Page C4.]

Lawyers for Stewart Request New Trial Again Martha Stewart's lawyers requested a new trial for her, arguing that lies told by a government witness prevented her from receiving fair treatment. The lawyers also asked for a hearing to determine whether any prosecutors knew that the witness was lying.

It is Ms. Stewart's second attempt at overturning the verdict against her. An earlier request, in which Ms. Stewart's lawyers said a juror had lied on a screening questionnaire, was rejected last month. [Page C4.]
United to Cut Retiree Benefits United Airlines reached a deal with unions on a plan to cut health care benefits for 50,000 retired workers and their family members. [C4.]

Stocks Gain in Short Trading Week Stocks made modest gains. The S.&P. 500 advanced 5.14 points, to 1,136.47. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.66 points, to 10,410.10. The Nasdaq composite index added 9.26 points, to 1,999.87. [C5.]
Financial Markets Are Closed Financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Ronald Reagan's funeral. They will reopen on Monday.

Following California on Emissions California's plan to sharply cut automotive emissions of global warming gases could eventually lead residents of other states to drive vehicles that are substantially cleaner than those in the rest of the nation. [C4.]
Chrysler Shows Efficiency Gains The Chrysler Group made the biggest gain in North American auto manufacturing efficiency last year, a study showed. [C4.]
U.S. Import Prices Increased 1.6% United States import prices rose 1.6 percent last month, the biggest increase in 15 months, the Labor Department reported. [C5.]
Critics of Nielsen File Lawsuit Critics of the changes Nielsen Media Research is making in how it measures television ratings in major urban markets have taken their fight to the courthouse. [C3.]

Longtime BBDO Executive Departs The generational changing of the guard at BBDO Worldwide accelerated with the unexpected departure of a longtime creative leader, Ted Sann. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C3.]

John Hancock Chief to Retire Manulife Financial, Canada's biggest insurer, said that David D'Alessandro would retire as chief executive of its John Hancock unit in the United States in November. Mr. D'Alessandro, 53, headed the insurance and financial services units of Boston-based John Hancock. He will be replaced by two senior vice presidents, James Benson and John DesPrez III, Manulife said in a statement. [C3.]

Judge May Unseal Oracle Evidence A federal judge is leaning toward unsealing much of the evidence that companies want to keep secret in the antitrust trial examining Oracle's $7.7 billion bid for PeopleSoft. [C2.]
Microsoft Files Spam Lawsuits Microsoft said that it had filed eight lawsuits against spammers. [C2.]

Signs of Economic Cooling in China China's industrial production and money supply grew at a slightly less brisk pace in May, evidence of economic moderation after signs of overheating. [World Business, Section W.]
U.S. Seeks Deal With Russia on Gas American officials are pursuing long-term natural gas export agreements with energy-rich Russia. [World Business, Section W.]
